Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Improving the Power Electronics used in Nuclear Fusion with New Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Electricity generated from nuclear fusion is being pursued as a cleaner alternative to power produced by burning fossil fuels and from uranium based nuclear fission. Power electronics are used in this process to control the electrical energy during the fusion reaction. If the efficiency of this hardware could be improved and its size reduced, it would contribute towards making this form of energy generation a reality. However, this is difficult to accomplish with existing components due to the properties of the materials used. As a potential solution, this research explores an alternative medium for constructing this hardware. The Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak (EAST) located at the Chinese Academy of Science in Hefei, China is one of the most advance reactors in the world. The power electronics used to control EAST will be the case study for this work. This research will be conducted in in collaboration with Dr. Lei Yang, an expert in this field of energy conversion. The results of this investigation will also be applicable to systems that are used to ensure grid stability in the United States and abroad.

The circuits controlling EAST use silicon (Si) thyristors to regulate the flow of electrical energy. This work studies the possibility of using silicon carbide (SiC) components as replacements. The atomic properties of SiC are superior to Si in many respects, making improvements in efficiency and power density achievable. This project will quantify the gains in terms of electrical efficiency and reduced footprints for a SiC based poloidal field (PF) power supply. Simulation results along with experimental data will be used to support the conclusions. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuclear fusion may be one the answers for meeting the world’s energy needs with minimal environmental impact.  Compared to the methods of generating electricity from fossil fuels, it requires significantly less fuel and it does not produce greenhouse gases during the reaction process. A tokamak machine, which produces the fusion reaction, requires a substantial amount of electricity, much of which is provided by high-power power supplies (HPPS). This hardware utilizes silicon (Si) switching devices to transform electricity from one form to another. With the recent advances in semiconductor manufacturing technology, a new generation of power devices have become available that could significantly improve the performance of the HPPS. This research explores the benefits of using one of these new materials, silicon carbide (SiC), in two different tokamak power supplies. Due to the similarity of this equipment with the topologies used in flexible AC transmission systems (FACTs), the findings of this research are also applicable to the electrical grid in the United States (US) and abroad.

Engineers are already improving the efficiency and decreasing the physical size of low to medium voltage power conversion hardware by using SiC transistors. This work sought to quantify the benefits of using SiC in the experimental advanced superconducting tokamak (EAST) located in Hefei, China. To accomplish this task, models of the vertical stability (VS) coil power supply and the neutral beam injection (NBI) power supply were created in Matlab Simulink. The resulting analysis predicts that the power loss in the switching devices of the VS coil power supply could be reduced by 66%. The NBI power supply losses could be decreased by 31% by replacing the Si components with SiC devices with the potential for a reduction up to 36 % by adding some additional control.

The ancillary benefits of this research project include strengthening the relationship between The Ohio State University (OSU), the Institute of Plasma Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ASIPP), Xi’an Jiaotong University and Chongqing University. At the two host universities, a presentation on wide bandgap power electronics research at OSU was given. The universities reciprocated with laboratory tours. The principle investigator (PI) was also able to participate in two separate events conducted by the ITER Organization. The first was a training session on the ITER Organization’s management principles. The second was the final design review meeting for the reactive power compensation and harmonic filtering system being installed at the ITER site in Cadarache, France.

The byproducts of this study include forming the basis of two independent studies for undergraduate students as well as a chapter in a dissertation. A Matlab Simulink model was created of the VS power supply that can be used for future evaluations of new power devices, as well as different control strategies. Additionally, future collaborations are now being planned between Miami University and ASIPP.
